entries.title: class-descriptions-completion-status
entries.content: Class Descriptions/Completion Status This section primarily exists to give you a starting point to see what you're interested in. Because this is early access, not all the classes are done\ (C) denotes that the class is complete, often with a variety of options\ (P) denotes the class is playable, but lacking in variety or later levels are sparse\ (ND) denotes the class is still in not done, and is largely unplayable Alchemist (ND)The scientist class. One of the more versatile classes that allows you to specialize in different types of fighting. Specialize in poisons, bombs, physical augmentations and more!Every single alchemist is completely unique thanks to their scientific discoveries.Beast Trainer (ND)The class name says it all: Form a close bond with a special animal uniquely trained to fight by your side. Beast companions can be tailored to fit very specific niches, or you can make a really big dino that chomps people. Also comes with a side of nature magic.Blood Hunter (P)A gunman with a crimson tint. You can sacrifice your life to continuously fire your firearm for massive damage. You fight to the last breath and hunt those that escape the bite of your bullets.Barbarian (C)The true bruiser class. The barbarian is designed to run straight into the middle of the battlefield all alone as their optimal strategy. They specialize in taking and dealing damage and equal measure, as well as disrupting the battlefield with combat maneuvers and raw strength, often in ridiculous ways.Bard (P)The cheerleader class. That's a bit of an exaggeration, but the bard is primarily concerned with supporting their team by inspiring them with tunes. Bards are at home in the middle of their team where they can provide the most benefit. They often excel in social situations. Their performances assure that whatever hijinks your party gets up to goes down in history.Bender (C)The elemental class. Based largely off of the "Avatar: The Last Airbender" and "Legend of Korra" anime. Based off of what element you choose, you will get a variety of abilities tailored to manipulating that element. Airbenders are mobile with the ability to glide and eventually fly. Firebenders specialize in dealing damage. Earthbenders are tough to keep down and bend the element with the most utility. Water benders are the best generalists with decent durability, healing and CC.Druid (C)The nature mage class. Focus on a particular element of nature, like beasts, plants, insects or fungi. This choice informs the nature of many of your class features. The druid excels in off-road adventures to the uninhabited corners of the world.Fiend Shifter (C)The demon class. Tailor yourself towards one specific type of fiend as they are depicted in folklore and popular media. Demons primarily deal in destruction, and grow to monstrous sizes with extra demon parts to get the job done. Devils primarily deal in deals, using the power of persuasion to lock people into promises as well as lock them in place. There are more, but I'll leave it at that for brevity.Fighter (C)Do they even really need a description? Your standard warrior class whose primary asset is their mastery over their equipment. Archetypes give variety in your game plan whether its zone control with Dark Knight, dueling with Swashbuckler or horde slaying with Aran.Hero (P)A class based off of the sillyness encountered in the Oldschool Runescape MMORPG. It is very flexible, with an emphasis on adding tons of new abilities that interact with skills, similar to the signature skill feat.Healer (P)The true support class. Provides the invaluable resource of healing, whether it means hitpoints, poisons or whatever other strange ailments that befall adventures.Jester (P)Bard felt too general for me, so they're primarily musicians now. Jesters are kind of an inbetween for bard and rogue. Part martial, part mage, with tons of supernatural abilities that allow them to get into and out of trouble based on acting, prestidigitation style magic and miming.Lunatic (C)The wild magic class. A full blown magic caster class similar to 5e's wild magic sorcerer. This class is meant to be a complete joke as far as flavor text goes. If you want your character to be completely unpredictable and completely insane, this is the one for you. Praise Frogg!Light Guardian (P)Light guardians are duty-bound to protect the world from the seemingly endless onslaught of fiends and mages who would take advantage of others. A very simple martial support class centered around preventing and protecting against magic.Martial Artist (C)The unarmed class. Your primary asset is your body and your spirit. Martial artists require no equipment in order to be functional, replacing weapons and armor with years of rigorous training. This class covers everything from monks to wrestlers.Magus (ND)The spell sword class. Not quite fighter not, quite wizard, the magus specializes in dealing damage with magic via their weapons. They get unique abilities that allow them to combine spells and attacks.Maligner (C)A class with a very specific theme. You no longer exist. Instead you are a set of interchangeable and replaceable personas. There is no "real you." Most of the maligner's abilities are centered around deceit through illusions, enchantments and transformations.Mechanic (ND) The mecha class. Has 2 variants: pilot and suitor. Pilots are the mecha classic where you hop into an oversized robot and use that for fighting, transportation etc. Suitors prefer a technologically advanced body suit (a la metroid) that enhances their combat prowess and comes with all kinds of useful adaptations and gadgets.Mesmerist (C)The hypnotist class. You have a very special pair of eyes that allow you to break the mental barriers of creatures just by staring at them. You cast spells that manipulate the minds of others and have a special set of psychic implants that you can use to create contingent effects like seeing through another creature's eyes or turning them into a sleeper cell.Necromancer (C)The undead master class. Every enemy that you defeat you are able to transform into an allied skeleton or zombie. Your abilities allow you to better maintain these creatures and also makes them more powerful. There are variants that are more catered towards a magic caster playstyle, and others that encourage you to get into the thick of things with your undead minions.Psychic (C)The psionic class. Your psychic powers allow you to manipulate objects with your mind, gaze into the minds of others and even manipulate their memories. There is a variant that specializes in the telekinesis, throwing objects (and creatures) around the battlefield. Another that specializes in scrying: A type of advanced magical spying technique that allows you to hear and see things from great distances. Another in reading and toying with the future.Rogue (P)The class that isn't afraid to use underhanded tactics. Rogue specialize in stealthy operations, are good with their hands and have high mobility. Rogues can be masterminds, creating nebulous plans that fall into place precisely when needed. Rogues can also be common thugs, specializing in bullying and intimidation.Shapeshifter (C)The animal transformer class. The shapeshifter has the ability to take on any number of features from different types of creatures, but mostly animals. They can choose to go an anthropomorphic hybrid mode, growing claws and jaws werewolf style, or they can choose to completely transform into animals. The wide variety of features that a shapeshifter can use and the swiftness of the transformations allows them to adapt to the situation on the fly.Summoner (???)The pokemon trainer class. The summoner summons a unique creature called an eidolon that fights by their side. As the summoner grows more powerful, they are able to shape the course of the creatures evolution, allowing them to create completely unique abominations from other realms. Outside of the eidolon, they're also able to summon other weaker creatures to supplement their main damage source.Slayer (P)The Doom class. Based largely off of the games "Doom: 2016" and "Doom Eternal." You are a one-man army with a deadly arsenal of unique guns, melee weapons and supernatural powers almost entirely dedicated to killing things. Even without these weapons, your fists are usually enough to get the job done.Virtuoso (P)Another unique gun wielding class. Primarily based off of the league of legends character Jhin. The virtuoso has a certain flair to their combat, creating flashy displays out of their gunplay. Fear the 4th shot.Wizard (ND)The magic caster with the biggest brain. Wizards possess the unique ability to memorize their spells on the fly. Given enough time for preparation, a skilled wizard can overcome any problem, including creating entirely new spells.Zealot (C)The crusader class. Zealots are shielded by their faith in god as much as their armor. They always take the moral high ground and have mercy for other creatures. Some creatures though, like undead and demons, are beyond redemption, and must be eliminated by using their divine powers to smite them into oblivion.

entries.title: distributing-ability-scores
entries.content: Distributing Ability Scores Read the core mechanics section in order to get a better understanding of the function of each ability score. Every character gets starting 6 points to invest in their ability scores as they wish/ Every point you increase in ability score counts against this total.\ You can decrease an ability score to -1 in order to gain an additional point. The maximum points you can invest is 3. The minimum is -1.

entries.title: main-character-status
entries.content: 🦸 Main Character Status Have you ever wanted to write an epic story for a character you made? How they survived a bloody conflict, went through incredibly rigorous training to become the best and brightest mage, was chosen by god or some other equally astonishing development. Then the game says "you die in one hit to a goblin." While not entirely unrealistic, it doesn't make for very satisfying gameplay to have your character feel like they are made out of paper and are one stray crit away from instant death. A game like DnD 5e remedies this by making KO'd a state your character falls in and out of multiple times as a result of "le nat 20," spammable low action healing and a lack of negative hit points. If you want the player characters to be invincible compared to monsters of a similar level, I say skip the pretense. Player characters are of a different breed and are hardened by their previous adventures, granting the following benefits… HP - Your hp is increased by 10.\ Defeat - You do not have a chance to instantly die when you fall unconscious, instead you receive a stacking debuff called doom. You also accumulate afflictions. With this change, a measure of how worn down you are can be more easily tied to how much hp you have. There are obviously other factors, but you can't ever keep adventuring without hp. Mana is the general resource system tied to using special abilities, and it naturally recharges when not used. In general healing that keeps you at full HP all the time is intended to be more scarce, and usually come at the cost of reducing your max mana until you rest. In general, only PCs will have this buff. But BBEGs, legendary creatures and other major bosses intended for use at the end of major story beats could also receive a similar version of this buff. Then you can get the juicy "phase transition" threshold to give your big boss encounters more punch.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Quick Character Creation Guide {% hint style="warning" %} Read main character status! It is essential for character creation. {% endhint %} There are several things for you to decide when deciding what you're writing down on your character sheet. Start with a theme, aesthetic, fighting style, or a particular character you want to mimic from popular media. There's nothing wrong with working backwards, but in general, I listed things from most important to least important when it comes to making your character sheet and starting to play. *  You should probably start with… 1ClassThe way that I've designed classes has generally been pretty specific in terms of theme. Some classes come with archetypes (subclasses).Some classes have choices pre-built in, like what type of techniques you know, a martial artist's fighting style or a necromancer's starting minion.2RaceRaces come with a variety of benefits. Primary race features help define what role they generally fit, while secondary features are generally more interchangeable.Human is kind of the "default" which is generally good for all characters and isn't very difficult to role play.3Ability ScoresRead up on what each of them do since they are all useful at a baseline! How you determine your stats is in the distributing ability scores subsection.  Then after that… 4SkillsSkills generally determine the type of things that your character does that are less specific. Rogues and ninjas might be known for stealth, but anybody can take the skill. Most skills are tailored towards out of combat interactions, but some like athletics, stealth and acrobatics have a variety of applications.5Feat(s)Feats are customization options that usually give static bonuses, new options in combat, and generally serve to tailor your character towards a specific play style.6BackgroundThis section helps inform what your character was up to before they became an adventurer and provides you with unique sets of starting gear.7EquipsDecide what type of weapon/armor you want.All character start off with 1,000g to spend as they wish as well as a jizzle physick (details also in equipment).  Then finally… 8BackstoryThink about what your character wants, the kinds of tie-ins they have to your world and the kinds of tragic events that happened that led to them brooding in corners of bars.Writing back stories can be fun, but you shouldn't feel obligated to write a specific number of pages or wordcount like it's some silly school assignment. How much you put into table top is how much you get out of it.The most important part of character design is making sure you, your DM and your players are all interested, or at the very least not annoyed, by your character.9?Random ChartsUnder the random charts section, there is a "character creation" tab that allows you to decide details about your character if you are uncertain about how big or small, old or young you want your character to be.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Classes Classes are the different types of characters you can play. Ill outline here what a typical class page looks like. Right here I give a brief description of the class. {% tabs %} {% tab title="Art" %} This is where I put art I think showcases the class well. I include sources where possible and I draw a lot of it. Click the other tab! {% endtab %} {% tab title="Basic Stats" %} Here I include a chart that lets you know some of the important stats related to the classes. Each of these stats are described in the rules section. | HP (martial) | 20(+10 per level) | | ---------------- | ----------------- | | Poise | 8 | | Skills | 4 | | Save Proficiency | Fort | | Memory | 2+lvl | {% endtab %} {% endtabs %} Level 1 Most characters will get their core abilities front-loaded at level 1. All classes get access to some type of techniques, whether its martial techniques or spells. Technique points granted through class usually have some form of restriction. Even Levels Even levels are mostly dedicated to class features that directly increase the classes power. Access to new combat abilities, increasing the power of old ones, getting their own special attacks.  Odd Levels (post level 1) Odd levels are mostly dedicated to getting the next tier of techniques. As such, class features are usually sparse. If any are included, they are usually minor increases in power or they are flavorful inclusions.\ You also get a feat every odd level. Level 11 Level 11 is an exception to the odd levels rule where most classes will earn some kind of capstone ability: Something that showcases mastery in whatever fighting style they possess. These features are usually purposefully designed to be overpowered and ridiculous. Level 12 Level 12 is the level where all player characters acquire ascensions. Ascensions are mostly class agnostic features that add a lot of customization to the final level in the game.\ Ascended characters are people that are incredibly significant to the world. These characters are the stuff of legend, and the abilities they acquire represent that. Their weapon becomes legendary, they become a demigod or they develop their own signature fighting style.

entries.title: anchoring-paint
entries.content: Anchoring Paint 800g (DC 20) For creatures who dislike pesky mages, plants that drain mana can be mixed with paint in order to create a liquid that can be spread over surfaces. Typically the paint comes with instructions on how you draw the magic circles required to activate its potential. A single can is enough to cover a 20 ft radius in a magic circles. Creatures cannot teleport to any surface that is warded by anchoring paint, or the air above it. After the paint has stopped an instance of teleportation, it rapidly begins to evaporate over the course of an hour.

entries.title: barbarian-chew
entries.content: Barbarian Chew Common, DC 16 (600g) These plants are rare occurrences in mountainous regions, but stand out due to their red leaves year round. With a little bit of alchemical alteration, they inspire fury in those that chew (and often consume) them. For the rest of the day, you cannot use \[concentration] effects. The next time you rage today you gain 10 additional speed. When this enhanced rage ends, you cannot rage again until you rest.

entries.title: embalming-fluid
entries.content: Embalming Fluid Cheap, DC 15 (150g) A slightly less extreme version of flash freeze, adapted for a specific purpose. Often used by morticians to make funeral rites more pleasant. Application of this ointment on a corpse prevents its decomposition and negates its stench for 1 week.  With 2 doses the embalming lasts a month.\ With 3 doses, and a creature trained in the medicine skill, it can last many years.

entries.title: flare
entries.content: Flare Cheap, DC 12 (70g) By mixing fuel with an oxidizer, all you need to make light is a spark. A flare provides a source of light that doesn't rely on fire, making it an ideal short term light source, or wet adventures. With a quick twist (swift action) to activate the chemical reaction, flares gives off light like a torch (20 ft radius bright) for 30 minutes. Flares are more resilient than torches in that they can be tossed around, even in water, without worry of the light going out. With such a simple triggering mechanism, flares can easily be attached to trip wires, or have some kind of specific firing mechanism similar to a firearm to activate it while launching it high in the sky, or both (just as examples).

entries.title: flash-freeze
entries.content: Flash Freeze Cheap, DC 11 (50g) Creating flash freeze requires the scale of a frost dragon to create, but the scale is a reusable component. Only small quantities of this substance can be created and contained at once. When poured over water, the oil pools on the surface and takes 1 round to spread out from the point of origin in a 20-foot radius. At the start of your next turn, the oil flash-freezes the surface of the water, creating an ice sheet over the affected area. Any 5-foot square of this ice can support \~500 pounds of weight. Weight in excess of this amount causes the entire sheet to crack and quickly break up. This ice sheet becomes unstable and breaks up on its own after 1 hour, or faster in a hot climate.  This item has no significant effect when used against creatures.

entries.title: perfume
entries.content: Perfume Cheap, DC 13 (90g) Perfumes are powerful mixtures of chemicals with distinct and long-lasting scents, made out of a wide variety of substances. Whether or not they are appealing is up to taste however. You can apply a dose of perfume to yourself as a standard action, and it lasts for a few hours, provided you are not drenched in other liquids or other powerful smelling substances. The first time you roll a persuasion check or deception check to lie against someone, roll serendipity. If you roll 17 or higher, the creature likes the smell, giving you a reroll against them for such checks. Creature's with the scent special quality tend to find most perfumes garish and unpleasant, increasing the DC to 20. Creatures without a sense of spell are unaffected by perfume. You can only benefit from a specific type of perfume's benefit once per creature, requiring you to spice things up during your next interaction if you want the reroll again. By succeeding on a monster lore check against a creature, or just asking people who may know such things, you can figure out a type of perfume they enjoy, bypassing the serendipity check entirely. Can also be flavor texted as a breath spray or something similar.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Other Utility

entries.title: salve-of-slipperiness
entries.content: Salve of Slipperiness Common, DC 15 (500g) Oils and secretions of all kinds can be used to make these salves. They are the most effective lubricant on the market, preventing friction in all kinds of scenarios.  Applying it to a creature takes 3 rounds and a thorough rub down. It temporarily gives them DR 10 vs grapples and the compression quality for 10 minutes.

entries.title: smelling-salt
entries.content: Smelling Salt Cheap, DC 10 (20g) A form of mineral too delicate for ore processing that requires an alchemist's touch to unlock its true potential. These crystals snap people awake in a hazy stupor when inhaled. Replaces the defeated condition with the time out condition until they restore hp, they take damage or 10 minutes pass.

entries.title: super-goo-solvent
entries.content: Super Goo/Solvent Common, DC 25 (1,000g) {% hint style="warning" %} This section mentions 2 different but interrelated items. Must be purchased separately. {% endhint %} A gooey substance gathered from goo dragons condensed and then separated into 2 components. Super goo takes all of the sticky qualities of a goo dragon and amplifies them. When exposed to open air for 1 round without being disturbed, it can bind any 2 surfaces to each other permanently. Nothing is stopping the objects from being torn or destroyed, however. Super solvent can negate the adhesive properties of super goo, as well as other "sticky" things like spider webs.

entries.title: agility-potion
entries.content: Agility Potion Common, DC 20 (800g) Rabbit's feet are a key component in creating agility potions. Other creatures known for swiftness are sometimes used as well. Gives a +10 bonus to speed and a +4 bonus to acrobatics checks for 1 minute, after which, the creature is fatigued. This effect is a \[buff].

entries.title: allnight
entries.content: Allnight Cheap, DC 14 (120g) Allnight is made from crushed nocturnal insects. The stimulant is similar to caffeine, but cranked up to 11. it is very easy to tell when someone is under the effects of all night due to their constant twitching/jittering and inability to remain focused. Lasts 8 hours. You suppress the negative effects of fatigue and cannot fall asleep or be put to sleep, but take a -2 penalty to all skill checks and cannot do anything with the \[concentration] tag. You also do not gain the benefits of rest while under the effects of allnight.

entries.title: antitoxin
entries.content: Antitoxin Cheap, DC 10 (20g) Anti toxin is a liquid that can be drank or directly applied to wounds as a standard action, depending on the type of poison. When administered it halts the progression of poison for 1 hour. Using multiple antitoxins on the same creature in the same 24 hour period has no effect.

entries.title: bloodblock
entries.content: Bloodblock Cheap, DC 15 (150g) Bloodblock requires extracting toxins from creatures like mosquitoes and removing the itchiness. Many alchemists do this by crushing large quantities of common mosquitoes and using chemical separation processes. Can be used to substitute for a med kit when treating bleeding creatures. Gives a +4 bonus said checks.

entries.title: gillweed
entries.content: Gillweed Cheap, DC 13 (90g) Gillweed is a plant commonly found in swamps at the waters edge. This potion must be inhaled instead of drank. Doing so is very uncomfortable and staggers the creature for 1 round. The potion allows a creature to breathe underwater as well as air for 8 hours.

entries.title: healing-potion
entries.content: Healing Potion Common, DC 18 (700g) The jizzle when it is not acclimated to a particular creature consumes a vast amount of resources from the creatures body to immediately speed up recovery. Immediately restores 5 hp. By increasing the DC by 4, you can double the price and increase its healing by 5. This doubling in price/+4 DC is cumulative (DC 22 for 700g, DC 26 1400g, DC 30 for 2800g etc) T3 and above potions are considered rare items due to their high craft DC.

entries.title: mana-potion
entries.content: Mana Potion Common, DC 18 (700g) By melting down mana crystals, they can be converted into a tasty sweet potion that can be addictive. Immediately restores 1 mana, but you mana burn 1, reducing your maximum mana. Normally mana burn also reduces current mana, but to keep the math simple, increase current mana by 1 and reduce max by 1. By increasing the DC by 4, you can double the price and increase its restorative effects and mana burn by 1. This doubling in price/+4 DC is cumulative (DC 22 for 700g, DC 26 1400g, DC 30 for 2800g etc) T3 and above potions are considered rare items due to their high craft DC.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Potions Potions are small flasks that can be downed in one gulp and usually provide some type of positive benefit to the consumer.\ Some potions inflict potion sickness. Potion Sickness - A creature with potion sickness cannot drink any other potions. Makes it so you can't drink in consecutive turns unless stated otherwise. (cycle goes as follows: drink, sick, drink etc...)

entries.title: tongues-potion
entries.content: Tongues Potion Common, DC 20 (800g) Tongues potions are made using the saliva of particularly chatty or loud creatures. When consumed, the potion allows you to sound like any creature. However, this drought is missing one final ingredient: The tongue of the creature you wish to sound like. Without this key ingredient, the potion is useless. Most tongues potions are sold without the final key ingredient, but alchemy stores tend to have a few preserved tongues lying around. Potions that already sound like a specific creature are incredibly rare and exorbitantly, but more general things like "orc" or "imp" might be available for sale. Depending on the rarity of the tongue in question, price could increase by 10% for something common like orc, or increase by 1,000% with the tongue of a prince. Roundabout numbers, decide as appropriate for situation. Big rare=big price.

entries.title: trollblood-potion
entries.content: Trollblood Potion Common, DC 20 (800g) By scraping off the natural excretions of a troll's skin, trollblood potions can be made. When consumed, the creature gains regeneration 1 for 1 minute. This effect is suppressed for 1 turn if the creature takes fire/poison damage. Trollblood gives you potion sickness.

entries.title: alchemist-fire
entries.content: Alchemist Fire 500g (DC 14) Alchemist fire is one of the first things taught to alchemists and only requires a handful of common chemicals. When exposed to open air, this combination of chemicals ignites. Creatures within 5 ft are set ablaze (DC 14 reflex negates).

entries.title: bottled-lightning
entries.content: Bottled Lightning 500g (DC 14) Typically alchemists create bottled lightning on stormy days, with some type of lightning rod to attract the lightning. They treat the interior of a bottle with a thin layer of a rubbery insulator and extract the stored electrical power into it. When destroyed, the lightning lashes out at nearby creatures. Creatures within 5 ft take 2d6 (7) zap damage (DC 14 reflex negates).

entries.title: chloroform
entries.content: Chloroform 800g (DC 20) Chloroform is mostly a product of a handful of mushrooms and seaweeds, its properties make it useful in a variety of alchemical creations, but the most well known use is its ability to knock creatures out. A handful of spells and plant creatures have adopted use of this "sleep powder" to incapacitate creatures temporarily. Alchemists have figured out how to manufacture chemicals that mimic this, but are significantly less powerful. Carefully sealed in glass jars, chloroform is used as a projectile weapon. Make a thrown attack against a creature or a melee attack to smash it against them. The creature must make a DC 20 fortitude save or become drowsy and a bit numb. This gives them blurred vision and 5 temp hp. If you critically strike the creature, it lands in their face and the has disadvantage on its save. By smashing a second glass jar against an already drowsy creature, they are forced to make an additional save. If they fail, they are put to sleep for 1 round.

entries.title: flash-powder
entries.content: Flash Powder Common, DC 11 (400g) When thrown with enough force, a bag of flash powder reacts violently with a flash of light. Thrown at a creature's feet, it blinds for 1 round (DC 14 reflex reduces to blurred vision). When consumed it makes the user feel very fast for no mechanical benefit.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Thrown Concoctions Thrown concoctions are alchemical items that can be used as thrown weapons in combat. Some thrown concoctions explode on impact, requiring a saving throw instead of an attack.

entries.title: siphoning-salt
entries.content: Siphoning Salt Common, DC 16 (600g) Mineral deposits containing salt exposed to powerful magic can sometimes cause the salt to take a blue hue, giving it anti-magic properties. Mages are hesitant to mass produce it for obvious reasons. When thrown on a spell with a persistent effect, it acts as dispel magic at CL 3.

entries.title: stink-oil
entries.content: Stink Oil Cheap, DC 11 (50g) Like alchemist fire, stink oil only requires common chemicals. It also requires a little bit of dead organic matter. Most alchemists use their own dead skin flakes to save time. Throw this vial in the space of a creature to cause it to be sickened 2 for one minute (DC 14 fort negates). Creatures with blindsense (scent) take a -2 penalty to their save. Regardless if the creature saves, survival attempts using scent get a +2 bonus until the creature washes up.

entries.title: divorce-potion
entries.content: Divorce Potion 2,600g (DC 30) It's so easy to fall in love, but much harder to climb out of it. The divorce potion negates the effects of the love potion. It uses many of the same ingredients but requires organic matter harvested from the creature who the creature is in love with. The effects of the potion are instant. The creature is fully aware of everything they did while under the effects of the love potion, but views it as they would have from the day just before they drank it.  Divorce potions are most commonly administered to fix accidental love potion consumption. Due to the higher DC, they are much less common.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Love Potion 800g (DC 20) By extracting the juices of a dead love bug, the complex process of creating a love potion can begin. The name is what everybody calls it, but its function is more in line with a toxin than a potion. Care must be exercised when using love potions, for love is not an exact science. When a creature consumes a love potion, they become charmed and deeply romantically interested in the first person they see for 8 hours. At the end of this duration, the creature loses the charmed condition. It then makes a will save (DC 20 negates) to resist the effects of the potion or the romantic feelings become permanent. In the event where the creature first seen is not romantically compatible, it instead forms a close platonic bond.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Toxins Toxins are harmful substances that usually require getting into the body of your target, either through injury or ingestion. Most of them inflict some type of debilitating status. An injury toxin can be applied to your weapon as a standard action, and typically evaporated within a few minutes. Applies its effect on-hit.

entries.title: styx-serum
entries.content: Styx Serum 2,400g (DC 27) Using a sample of water from the river Styx and some brain matter, you can create a concoction that can wipe a creature's memories of the recent past. It looks a bit foggier than water and tastes like stagnant water. The Styx serum is incredibly powerful when ingested. It wipes out the memories of the last 24 hours, including drinking the serum. Particularly important events, such as a first kiss, a loved one dying or an unexpected betrayal cannot be erased completely from the spirit by the Styx serum. Such events are instead interpreted as gut feelings, fated connections, love at first sight or deja vu,

entries.title: README
entries.content: ⚗️ Alchemical Items Come in several different categories based on their typical use case. The format includes the items name, the DC to craft it and its cost to purchase. I put alchemical items into different price brackets. One for relatively minor and commonplace items another for powerful items, and the last for things requiring incredibly rare reagents.  Item DC refers to craft DC, which determines the price. The save DC is typically a base amount (or the class DC of the Alchemist class). If you want to purchase items with a higher DC, adjust the price accordingly. Cheap - DC^2-80. Then rounded up to nearest 10. Common - 100+(DC+5)^2. Then rounded up to nearest 100 Expensive - 1000+(DC+10)^2. Then round up to nearest 100

entries.title: businessman
entries.content: Businessman You are one of owners of a large business, or the primary owner of a small business. Choose a specific profession, craft or performance skill that you are proficient in, or that could be reasonably related.  You have access to a location that you can perform all of the necessary tasks of your trade. This location counts as masterwork tools for whatever it is. In addition, you make 10% more money when you work here. You have to return to this business for at least twice each month for upkeep. If you have a method of long distance communication good enough to have lengthy back and forths, such as a good postal system or magic, you can also upkeep as long as you send such messages 1/week. If you don't you are replaced or the business begins to decline.

entries.title: family-man
entries.content: Family Man You are the co-owner of a house somewhere in the world, usually at least on the tangent of civilization. You lived with either your immediate family, like parents and siblings, or you made a family of your own with a spouse and children. You own a meager house in a specific place, and a handful of family members to come home to after an adventure. Your house is always considered a suitable place to rest in order to cure general afflictions. Your family generally understands you won't always be back home for dinner, but going more than a month without contact will usually cause them unease, and may eventually cause them to move.

entries.title: noble
entries.content: Noble You come from an upper ring of society. Your name might not carry the same weight everywhere you go, but your gold pouch certainly does. You get a bonus 1,000 starting gold that you can spend as you wish. Your family also gives you an allowance every month of 500g. For campaigns with a faster or slower pace, such as if there are frequent time skips, consider changing how often the allowance comes in. If you are far from home, it can take up to a week for your allowance to arrive. They can only ever be picked up from settlements.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Background Background helps to determine what your character was doing before they got sucked up into an adventure, other than acquiring the skills necessary to go out into the dangerous world of course. Backgrounds typically give assets with a specific focus.

entries.title: tradesman
entries.content: Tradesman You worked in a job that required a specialized form of training, such as an alchemist, a doctor or a blacksmith. Over the years of your work you have accumulated a few tools of the trade.  Select one of the following presets, or make one that's similar.  Doctor - You start off with a masterwork medicine kit, a dose of troll oil and 3 doses of bloodblock. Alchemist - Start off with a masterwork alchemist kit. You start off with a love potion and an alchemist fire. Craftsman (weapons/armor) - Start off with a set of combat ready equipment. You can start off with...\ -Heavy armor and a weapon\ -Medium armor, 3 melee weapons, a ranged weapon and a shield\ -Light armor, 6 light melee weapons, 2 ranged weapons and a shield You also have masterwork tools for crafting weapons/armor.

entries.title: wanderer
entries.content: Wanderer You go wherever the road takes you. You might have had a home once, but for one reason or another you had to or wanted to leave. You start play with a standard rock. More information can be found in the bestiary. Very basically, rocks are autonomous, mass produces transportation and shipping vehicles. Most significant places in civilization will have service stations and parking available.

entries.title: mana-donation
entries.content: Mana Donation By going to specialized facilities, or by going to churches with gilded altars, a creature can donate mana. When you donate, you \[mana burn] an equal amount. A creature can safely donate an amount of mana equal to their (max-1). There are usually safeguards against donating your max mana, but less savory individuals don't mind. Mana burning your max mana gives you a T3 affliction: Mana Starvation. This means that most common people are only able to donate 1 mana each day. Children typically do not possess enough mana to safely donate. Specialized facilities and gilded altars are incredibly expensive, typically costing 100s of thousands of gold to craft. This makes it so facilities for mana donation tend to be rather sparse, only located in sizable settlements with magical and religious influence. When mana is extracted, it is turned into a mana crystal. Mana crystals are versatile and can change between states of matter, becoming either liquid or solid for ease of storage. Each point of mana can earn 4g in a mana extraction facility. In a church, it earns 5 GBP and food/lodging for the day. Accumulation of Mana Most religious services happen in the evening after work, so that way people may spend their mana as they wish during the day, and donate it at night if they wish. With large generous populations this can mean that you can amass large quantities of mana rather quickly. Because most people can only donate 1 mana, you can almost 1:1 translate a population of donors to daily mana generation. Not everybody who donates has commoner tier mana, but at the same time, not everybody can always donate! So the 1:1 ratio is generally the go-to method of determining mana generation over time. Again, not all places have the correct facilities, so this is often available in villages.

entries.title: populations
entries.content: Populations Settlements receive classifications based on population. More populous settlements tend to condense more wealth, have more facilities and are more cosmopolitan. Certain types of services can be expected in larger settlements, but are unheard of in smaller ones. The settlements of Nack are generally less populous than those in our world, with even the biggest of cities having only hundreds of thousands of people. Hamlet - Village - 1,000+ people City - 10,000+ people Metropolis - 100k+ people Some general assumptions about the population... * About 10% of the population is assumed to be over level 0, with a skew towards early levels. * Most regions have a dominant religion, with at around half the population favoring them. Metropolises break this mold by having more variety, while hamlets tend to have a much higher skew of 1 religion.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Economics This section is dedicated to determining income, typically through the use of a skill, like profession, perform or alchemy. All income is based around a formula which calculates a yearly salary (y) based on your skill bonus (x). y=5000+500(10+x^2) Salary assumes you you work for 5 days a week, for 50 weeks a year. Divide this value by 250 to figure our your daily income. Most jobs tend to have weekly payouts. The chart below does this formula for you for most expected values. Anything lower than a +0 bonus to the task at hand makes a 5k salary, 20g daily and 100g a week. This formula assumes a prosperous nation with a lot of economic opportunity and a population with thousands of people per city. In poorer and less populous regions, consider using the following multiplier for all goods and services (if you don't mind sacrificing convenience for realism, since multiplying the value every time you buy/sell can get tedious). Developing - Multiply all values by .75\ Poor - Multiply all values by .5 It also assumes the work provides value. If you are a butcher in a society of vegans, you will struggle to find work. Apply a multiplier in such circumstances. Service/Goods is Almost Useless - Multiply all values by .1\ High Supply/Low Demand- Multiply all values by .5\ Low Supply/High Demand, Novel Service- Multiply all values by 1.2 Skill Bonus (x)

entries.content: Prices/Weight of Common Equipment Characters start off with 1k gold.
