entries.title: README
entries.content: Antagonize Requirements -  You can taunt a creature for one round instead of making them shaken when you demoralize them. You can also use deception just like you would intimidation in order to achieve this effect. The opponent rolls a will save with a DC of 10+your deception bonus. You can continue this taunt by spending a swift action each turn, as long as you are still within 30 ft of your target.

entries.title: scapegoat
entries.content: Scapegoat Requirements - Antagonize When you use the antagonize feat to taunt a creature, you can instead make it taunted by any ally.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Combat Reflexes Requirements -  You can draw a weapon as part of an attack of opportunity if you have a free hand. Gain two additional AoOs. Opponents can tell you continue to threaten past the first AoO.

entries.title: sentinel
entries.content: Sentinel Requirements -  * Whenever you land an AoO against a creature that attempts to move out of your threatened spaces, their movement is halted and their speed is reduced to zero for their turn * The first time a turn a creature you threaten attacks an ally (that isn't you), make an AoO against it

entries.title: big-game-tussler
entries.content: Big Game Tussler Requirements - Maneuver Initiate You can combat maneuver creatures of any size with no penalty, regardless of your strength.

entries.title: directed-disarm
entries.content: Directed Disarm Requirements - Maneuver Initiate Whenever you disarm a creature, you can choose a space within 15 ft for the disarmed item to land.

entries.title: linebacker
entries.content: Linebacker Requirements - Maneuver Initiate * You shove creatures 5 ft farther, or 10 ft if you charge. * If your foe impacts a solid surface or an object when you shove them, they break it if is of average or lesser toughness.  * If you shove a creature into an object or surface, they also take 5 damage (usually crush, adjust as appropriate). If the object or surface is particularly dangerous, like a weapon rack or a glass window, then the damage increases to 10. * If you shove a creature into another creature, they both take 5 crush damage.

entries.title: maneuver-master
entries.content: Maneuver Master Requirements - Maneuver Initiate The first time a turn you poise break a creature, it provokes AoOs from all of your allies minus you.

entries.title: mine
entries.content: Mine! Requirements - Maneuver Initiate * When you disarm a creature, you can immediately wield the weapon you steal. If you don’t have a free hand, you can drop equipment to hold the disarmed gear. * You get a +2 bonus to attack with weapons you have disarmed from your opponents this combat. * You get a +2 bonus to CL with a spell focus you have disarmed from your opponents this combat.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Maneuver Initiate Requirements -  As an instant action 1/round, gain +4 to your next attack that is a combat maneuver. You can replace simple attacks with combat maneuvers, unless it is an additional attack granted by dual wielding.

entries.title: swift-grappler
entries.content: Swift Grappler Requirements - Maneuver Initiate Maintaining a grapple only requires one attack from your multi-attack or a swift action.

entries.title: tangled
entries.content: Tangled Requirements - Maneuver Initiate While grappling a creature, gain DR 5 vs poise damage and +2 AC.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Point Blank Master Requirements - Dex +1 Your ranged attacks are \[elusive].

entries.title: snap-shot
entries.content: Snap Shot Requirements - Point Blank Master You threaten spaces within your natural reach with ranged weapons.

entries.title: lightning-reload
entries.content: Lightning Reload Requirements - Rapid Reload Your hands are a blur while reloading, cranking back crossbows and loading bullets with such incredible dexterity it borders superhuman. For crossbows, you can spend 1 mana as an instant action. Reloading with your crossbow no longer requires an action for 1 round. For firearms, you can reload your gun as an instant action by spending 1 mana for each shot.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Rapid Reload Requirements -  A weapon with the reload property can be shot and reloaded as a standard action, or a FRA with a gun. If the weapon isn't loaded, you can reload it then fire it as a standard action (or FRA with gun).

entries.title: README
entries.content: Shield Focus Requirements -  You can use a shield feature as an instant action 1/round. Gain a new shield action, usable as an immediate action.\ Shield Crash - When a creature misses you or grazes you with a melee attack, you can knock them down (fort negates).

entries.title: the-wall
entries.content: The Wall Requirements - Shield Focus When you wield 2 shields * You can use the shield special attacks (shield slam/endure) any number of times per battle. * Gain a +2 bonus to AC against any enemy you attack with a shield for 1 round. * Tank up does not cost any movement to activate and it does not reduce your speed, effectively allowing you to always tank up, but still only ever in 1 direction.

entries.title: ambrosia
entries.content: Ambrosia Requirements - Wis +1 You are gifted a pouch from your deity. At the end of each rest, if the pouch is empty, it is filled with food from your god. The ambrosia can be eaten using the same action as "drink potion (usually swift)" or "administer potion (usually standard)." It heals (7+2\*lvl) and nourishes as a full meal.

entries.title: back-to-the-wall
entries.content: Back to the Wall Requirements -  You cannot be flanked as long as you are adjacent to a wall. You are considered flanking a creature that is adjacent to a wall.

entries.title: blind-fight
entries.content: Blind Fight Requirements -  * You are not DD while blinded. * You have no attack penalty when attacking a creature with partial concealment. * You only have -2 attack penalty when attacking a creature with total concealment.

entries.title: bodyguard
entries.content: Bodyguard Requirements -  When an ally is moved out of your natural reach (via its own volition or not), you can move as an instant action so that it is again in your natural reach. Any movement you take using this feat counts against your movement for this round. If you cannot reach your ally, you can move as close as you can get. You can position yourself in the most advantageous way around your ally, assuming you have the movement.

entries.title: bonded-weapon-su
entries.content: Bonded Weapon (Su) Requirements -  Gain the ability to perform a 10 minute ritual that allows you to bond with 2 specific weapons. You gain DR 10 against disarm combat maneuvers made against these weapons. When you throw these weapons, they automatically return to your hand after the attack is resolved \[teleportation] if desired. If these weapons somehow manage to leave your possession otherwise, you can spend a swift action to have them return to your hand \[teleportation].

entries.title: bullseye
entries.content: Bullseye Requirements -  Carefully line up a ranged attack and increase the action required to make it to a FRA. Ignore the -4 penalty for shooting in the second range increment.  If your target is in the first increment, instead gain +2 attack. For effects that don't have range increments, such as spells, you can increase the action to cast to a FRA to gain the +2 bonus to attack.

entries.title: butterfly-sting
entries.content: Butterfly Sting Requirements -  Whenever you critically strike a creature, you can turn it into a regular hit instead and choose to let the next attack another ally lands against them be an automatic crit, so long as it at least hits them. There is no bonus effect if the next attack is normally a crit. If another ally attacks the creature, they automatically consume this effect, and cannot "store it" until a later turn.

entries.title: clustered-shots
entries.content: Clustered Shots Requirements -  When you make multiple range attacks against the same creature, only apply their damage reduction once.

entries.title: combat-step
entries.content: Combat Step Requirements - Dex +2 Reduce your speed to 5 this turn to make your movement \[elusive].

entries.title: combat-vigor
entries.content: Combat Vigor Requirements - Str +3 Gain FH 2.

entries.title: defensive-training
entries.content: Defensive Training Requirements -  Increase your poise by 5.

entries.title: diehard
entries.content: Diehard Requirements - Str +1 * The first time per day your hp would be reduced to 0, instead reduce it to 1. * The first time per day you are actually reduced to 0, you make make a simple attack immediately before you are defeated.

entries.title: distance-thrower
entries.content: Distance Thrower Requirements -  Thrown weapons have no penalty to attack in the second range increment.

entries.title: divine-interference
entries.content: Divine Interference Requirements - Wis +1 As an immediate action you can expend a use of prayer to reroll an attack directed against you or an ally within 30 ft.

entries.title: dual-wielding-versatility
entries.content: Dual-Wielding Versatility Requirements -  * You can dual wield with any 1h weapon, not just light weapons. * When dual wielding, you can sacrifice your "off hand" attack to gain advantage with your "main hand" attack. * You can also sacrifice your "off hand" attack to feint a creature. You must use your "main hand" to attack the creature you feinted.

entries.title: elemental-adept
entries.content: Elemental Adept Requirements -  Choose an elemental damage type (holy, force, etc). Whenever you deal damage of this type, it ignores resistance. Creatures immune to this damage type are instead treated as resistant. This is usually represented by something unusual for your element, such as a different color. Black fire, green lightning etc.

entries.title: fan-club-companion
entries.content: Fan Club \[companion] Requirements - Level 3, Cha +1 You use your influence and charm to gain a group of people that appreciate you. They are often willing to perform minor tasks for you, stick their neck out for you, but not risk their life for you. They are located in one specific place at first, then they may branch as you gain more levels and influence. The size of your fan club varies based on your level. You multiply this value by your charisma bonus. LevelFan Club Members334651061572283395010751112012250 One member of your fan club is your biggest fan. Your biggest fan is always a minion, other than that, there are no restrictions for what your biggest fan can be. When you gain this feat, you decide their class, race, stats etc. They count as a \[companion] if they travel with you. Your biggest fan doesn't necessarily need to be a playable race, but those that aren't should be acquired through story related encounters rather than chosen.

entries.title: fearsome-finisher
entries.content: Fearsome Finisher Requirements -  When you defeat a creature, gain a +4 bonus to intimidation checks for the rest of combat. Whenever you defeat a creature, you can demoralize another creature as a free action. If they were already shaken, they instead are frightened for 1 round

entries.title: fighters-lament
entries.content: Fighter's Lament Requirements -  When a creature teleports within your reach, it provokes an AoO.

entries.title: fleet-footwork
entries.content: Fleet Footwork Requirements -  Increase your base speed by 5ft. Your movement is \[elusive] against any target you have attacked this turn.

entries.title: ghostbuster
entries.content: Ghostbuster Requirements - Religion Proficiency You treat incorporeal creatures as though they were corporeal.

entries.title: heavy-metal
entries.content: Heavy Metal Requirements - Character level 3 You gain the following special attack, usable at-will with any 2h weapon. Special Attack: Vital Strike - Add d6 damage to your attack. This improves by an addtional d6 every odd level (max ).

entries.title: in-the-rhythm
entries.content: In the Rhythm Requirements -  The first time you miss an attack each turn, add to 2 to a pool. As an immediate action, you can expend all of this pool to increase the bonus of an attack roll you make. Problems: Doesn't do anything if you hit, making the payoff iffy unless you have many attacks. But the attack bonus is less significant for dual wielding. Can also be used to have the juggernaut morde q effect, stack on minions, one shot enemy with big attack.

entries.title: innocuous-bending
entries.content: Innocuous Bending Requirements - Elemental Blast, Sleight of Hand or Deception proficiency You can use sleight of hand's concealed weapon feature with your elemental blast. It does not require a swift action to use, but it only works once in a particular encounter. You can also use deception's sucker punch feature with your elemental blast without taking a penalty.

entries.title: mage-slayer
entries.content: Mage Slayer Requirements - Arcana Proficiency The first time you land a melee attack against a creature that is concentrating on a spell each round, they must roll a fortitude save (against your DC) or the spell is dismissed. You can also make a ranged attack, but the fort save is your DC-4.

entries.title: matador
entries.content: Matador Requirements -  When a creature grazes you or misses you with a charge attack, you can force them to continue their charge the full distance past you, potentially provoking AoOs. You can also choose to make them take a right angle turn. If they impact a solid surface, they take 10 crush damage.

entries.title: parting-shot
entries.content: Parting Shot Requirements -  When you take the disengage action, you make a simple ranged attack.

entries.title: power-pose
entries.content: Power Pose Requirements - Damage Reduction When you are damaged with an effect that your DR applies against, you can increase that DR by 5 as an immediate action. If the creature is within reach, it takes 10 poise damage.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Combat Feats A combat feat is only useful during combat, or is at least more skewed towards being useful during combat.

entries.title: ricochet-toss
entries.content: Ricochet Toss Requirements -  Whenever you make a thrown weapon attack, the weapon you throw returns back to your hand immediately, allowing you to continuously make attacks with the same weapon(s) in the same turn. {% hint style="warning" %} If a weapon's special effect requires being on the opponent to function (such as exotic weapons like nets), then you cannot ricochet them. {% endhint %} You also ignore the attack penalty from using thrown weapons in their second range increment.

entries.title: sniper
entries.content: Sniper Requirements - Stealth proficiency After making a ranged attack (or a ranged multiattack), you can hide as an immediate action, rolling stealth against only your target(s). If you succeed, they are unaware of your position, though can still assume your general direction.

entries.title: suppressing-fire
entries.content: Suppressing Fire Requirements -  As a standard action, you can prepare to cover an ally's movement using a ranged weapon you can make ranged attacks with. They are treated as though they took the disengage action on their next turn.

entries.title: toughness
entries.content: Toughness Requirements -  Increase your max hp by 5+lvl.

entries.title: trick-shot
entries.content: Trick Shot Requirements -  You can make combat maneuvers with ranged attacks at a -4 penalty. You are limited to bully, shove, topple, disarm.

entries.title: tumbling-charge
entries.content: Tumbling Charge Requirements -  When you charge, you can choose to charge through an enemy, rolling around them or running straight through them. This is \[elusive] against the target of your charge. You can end your charge on the opposite side of the creature instead of ending it when you meet the creature. You must still have the movement to do so.  You gain flanking against a creature you tumbling charge for the rest of your turn.

entries.title: unarmed-combatant
entries.content: Unarmed Combatant Requirements -  Even while unarmed you threatened with punches and kicks. Your unarmed strikes deal d8 dmg. Gain 2 special attacks usable with unarmed strikes. Spacial Attack: Blunt Force Trauma - On hit stagger your target for one round (fort negates). If this attack defeats the target, make a thrown weapon attack using the defeated creature as ammunition (no MA penalty). Spacial Attack: Power Fist - On hit stagger your target for one round (fort negates). If this attack defeats the target, it flies 1,000 ft into the air and gently lands on the ground one minute later. With a low roof, the creature is launched less high, but for just as long.

entries.title: unconventional-mount
entries.content: Unconventional Mount Requirements -  You have adapted your riding style to accommodate for smaller creatures. You can mount creatures that are the same size as you. You can mount any willing creature, even those without the proper hardware to facilitate mounting.

entries.title: unstoppable
entries.content: Unstoppable Requirements -  * You take no penalty to speed while staggered or frosty. This can reasonably extend to other minor temporary speed debuff abilities that aren't these exact status conditions (such as the speed penalty from the icicle cantrip). * If knocked down, your speed only decreases by 15. * If you would be unable to move at all, such as being stunned, entangled or grappled, your speed is instead 5.

entries.title: weapon-focus
entries.content: Weapon Focus Requirements -  Choose one: slash, pierce or crush You can use the default special attacks of these weapon types (cleave/lacerate, lunge/pierce defense, backbreaker/concussive strike) at-will. You also gain a new one depending on the type you chose, usable 1/combat. Slash: Great Cleave - Attack all creatures within reach Pierce: Impale - Creature struck provokes an AoO if they move by the start of your next turn. Crush: Pulverize - Stagger on hit (fort negates) The default and newly acquired special attacks also add your level to damage. {% hint style="success" %} If you have the unarmed combatant feat, then you can apply the effects of weapon focus (crush) to the special attacks granted by it. {% endhint %}

entries.title: README
entries.content: Skill Focus Requirements -  * Choose one skill. You roll it with advantage.  * When you take 10 with this skill, you instead take 15.  * If a feature calls for you to use 10+(skill bonus) as a DC for something, instead use 15+DC.

entries.title: signature-skill
entries.content: Signature Skill Requirements - Skill Focus in chosen skill You gain additional options in how to use a specific skill that you specialize it. For more information visit the skills page.

entries.title: convenient-companion-su
entries.content: Convenient Companion (Su) Requirements - Companion creature As a standard action, you can touch your companion creature to turn them into a tiny action figure version of themselves, provided they are willing. As a standard action, you can toss this action figure up to 30 ft away to transform it back. If you are currently in combat.

entries.title: cunning
entries.content: Cunning Requirements -  Gain proficiency in a skill.

entries.title: demolitionist
entries.content: Demolitionist Requirements -  Gain a +4 bonus to athletics checks made to destroy or displace objects

entries.title: intimidating-prowess
entries.content: Intimidating Prowess Requirements -  You can add your charisma and strength to intimidation.

entries.title: lead-by-example
entries.content: Lead by Example Requirements -  Whenever you perform a skill check you are proficient in, such as sneaking past someone or swimming across a raging river, anybody that follows your lead on their next turn gets a +10 bonus to the same check. If the task requires more than one turn for you to perform, your allies still get the bonus. If you fail the skill check, your allies do not get the bonus.

entries.title: photographic-memory
entries.content: Photographic Memory Requirements - +2 Int By spending a memory slot as a free action, you can memorize everything you are currently looking at, as though taking a photo. When looking back at this memory, you can comb it for further details, such as reading text or inspecting faces in a crowd. You can only memorize one such scene at a time.

entries.title: README
entries.content: General Feats General feats mostly assist with some kind of out of combat task, such as things to increase the consistency of skills.

entries.title: taking-prisoners
entries.content: Taking Prisoners Requirements -  You know how to keep a creature down. As a standard action against a defeated creature, you can perform a series of nonlethal blows in key places to make it so they cannot lose the defeated condition until they rest or someone performs a medicine check against them (class DC).

entries.title: wild-empathy
entries.content: Wild Empathy Requirements -  Gain proficiency in persuasion, but only for use against beasts. If you are already proficient in persuasion, gain a +2 bonus when using it against beasts. Base DC is 10+(creatures level). Add +2 to DC for things like the following: protecting young, is only beast adjacent (magic cow), abused by humanoids, starving, unfamiliar environment, mating season etc. Succeeding on a wild empathy check makes the creature friendly to you temporarily, allowing you to make simple requests. Beasts are dumb so their help is limited (which one of these guys hurt you, lead me to x). The most obvious use case is to inquire about strange things in the nearby area that have happened recently. Interacting with the same animal over time can give you bonuses or cause you to not need to make a check anymore.

entries.title: callous-casting
entries.content: Callous Casting Requirements -  As a swift action, increase the DC of an instantaneous spell you cast this turn by 2 if you include any non-minion allies (including yourself) in its AoE. {% hint style="danger" %} If you have an ability to effectively not include allies in an AoE, then you do not get the bonus of this feat.\ If the ally is immune or resistant to the effect, then you do not get the bonus of this feat. {% endhint %}

entries.title: magic-initiate
entries.content: Magic Initiate Requirements -  You gain access to 3 cantrips

entries.title: matryoshkasting
entries.content: Matryoshkasting Requirements - Level 3 When you use a level 2 or higher spell, the next spell of a lower level that you cast costs 1 less mana. This can chain together until you spend 0 mana on casting a spell. If a spell you cast is of the same level or a higher level than the one you cast last, the effect ends. For the purposes of this feat, a spell is considered of a higher level when you upcast it.

entries.title: mm-caster-minion
entries.content: MM Caster Minion Requirements - Int +2 While using a feature with the \[scrying] tag through a companion creature, you can use your actions and the creature's actions to have them be the origin point of your spells.

entries.title: mm-coax
entries.content: MM Coax Requirements - Int +1 Your spells with the \[mind affecting] tag can affect mindless creatures.

entries.title: mm-elemental-shift
entries.content: MM Elemental Shift Requirements - Int +1 When you cast the spell that deals an elemental damage type, you can choose to transform it into a different element, choosing between fire, frost, zap and force.

entries.title: mm-explosion-anticipation
entries.content: MM Explosion Anticipation Requirements - Int +0 You are immune to the effects of your own AoE spell, provided it does not have a listed duration.

entries.title: mm-focused-blast
entries.content: MM Focused Blast Requirements - Int +1 When you cast a spell that deals damage and targets multiple creatures, choose a "primary target." The DC of the spell for that creature is 2 higher. If the spell allows attacks against multiple creatures (such as Gloom Bolt), you also get a +2 bonus to attack against this creature.

entries.title: mm-intensify
entries.content: MM Intensify Requirements - Int +1 Increase the CL of the spell by 2.

entries.title: mm-latent-curse
entries.content: MM Latent Curse Requirements - Int +0 Your spells with the \[curse] descriptor can also be cast on items. The first creature to activate or put on this item is afflicted with the curse (save negates). If the save is successful, the curse is lifted. For items that aren't activated or worn (such as a rock) the creature must possess the item or at least 1 minute for the curse to take hold. With curses that allow for a creative uses, the parameters must be set at the time the spell is cast. {% hint style="info" %} SPECIAL: You can only curse three items at a time. When a curse afflicts a creature that plays with your protected items, it no longer counts against this total. If you cast another latent curse with 3 already active, you choose which item is no longer cursed. You have an innate sense when one of your latent curse spells is triggered. {% endhint %}

entries.title: mm-merciful-spell
entries.content: MM Merciful Spell Requirements - Int +0 Creatures defeated by this spell have no chance of dying when defeated by it. Any of its damaging aftereffects disappear when the creature is defeated.

entries.title: mm-persistence
entries.content: MM Persistence Requirements - Int +1 When you cast a spell that has recurring saves each turn, you can choose to give it the \[concentration] tag (if it doesn't already have it) in order to increase the DC of recurring saves by 2.

entries.title: mm-residual-damage
entries.content: MM Residual Damage Requirements - Int +2 When you cast a spell that deals damage that doesn't already have a damage over time effect, add one. The creature takes your CL in damage at the end of its turn for 1 turn if it fails its save. The type of damage matches the damage of the spell.

entries.title: mm-saviors-arrow
entries.content: MM Saviors Arrow Requirements - Int +1 You can fire the effect of a spell with the \[healing] tag using the range of a ranged weapon. If the healing spell can target multiple creatures, you can make as many attacks as you like, but cannot target an ally more than once. You can also choose to target a space to be the origin point of your spell. {% hint style="success" %} As part of using this feat, you can swap to a ranged weapon, then swap back to your staff. {% endhint %}

entries.title: mm-sniping
entries.content: MM Sniping Requirements - Int +1 Add +4 to an attack roll made with a spell.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Magic Feats Magic - Feats that specifically apply to spells. MM - Short for meta magic. A subsection of magic feats that allow you to apply general augments to spells by increasing the mana cost by 1. Most require intelligence.

entries.title: spell-ambush
entries.content: Spell Ambush Requirements - Stealth Proficiency Your spell DC is 2 higher against creatures you successfully hide from using stealth (aka if they would normally be DD from hiding). This only applies to the spell's initial save. This does not apply to other ways to cause a target to be DD, such as blinding them or feinting.

entries.title: spell-sharing
entries.content: Spell Sharing Requirements -  When you cast a single target spell with the \[buff] tag, you can cast it on a companion creature and yourself, or all of your companion creatures (provided they are in range and valid targets). This functions even if the spell has a target of self. If the spell does not have a listed range, its range for determining when you can buff your companions is reach.

entries.title: threatening-illusion
entries.content: Threatening Illusion Requirements -  When you create a \[figment] effect that creates a creature (such as imagination), it also threatens and provides flanking as long as creatures have not saved to disbelieve. As a standard action, or as an AoO, you can have the figment attack a creature. The creature takes d6 per spell level psychic damage (will negates and creature disbelieves illusion).

entries.title: bending-initiate
entries.content: Bending Initiate Requirements -  You can use the benders elemental blast feature as a character of (your level-2). It is a special attack that is usable any number of times a combat. The element you choose cannot be changed.

entries.title: ex-guardian
entries.content: Ex-Guardian Requirements -  Perhaps you used to be a light guardian a long time ago, or you dropped out of your training early. You gain the Light Guardian's Light Binding special attack. You can only use it once per combat. You do not gain any of the other class abilities that enhance it.

entries.title: flurry
entries.content: Flurry Requirements - Unarmed Combatant You can mimic a martial artists ability to weave punches and kicks into their combos. Any turn you do not make a multiattack, you can spend 1 mana to make a simple unarmed attack as a swift action.

entries.title: light-steps
entries.content: Light Steps Requirements - Level 3 Light steps requires concentration, and you can start concentrating on this ability as a free action by spending 1 mana.\ As long as you only move during your turn and take no other action, you can walk along any flat continuous surface. This can include things that aren't even otherwise solid such as water or lava. It can also include things such as walls or ceilings. You can use this ability for only part of your turn to get to a location, but if you attack, cast a spell etc, then you need a surface you would normally be able to stand on or you plummet.

entries.title: pet-companion
entries.content: Pet \[companion] Requirements - Level 3, Cha +0 You get a beast companion minion as per the beast trainer class feature. {% hint style="info" %} Minion: Its level is limited to 1/3 your level. {% endhint %}

entries.title: README
entries.content: Multiclass Multiclass - This feat allows you to borrow a feature from another class. Usually such features are secondary features of the class, or are there for flavor.

entries.title: speak-for-the-dead-su
entries.content: Speak for the Dead (Su) Requirements - Level 3 1/day you can use the Medium Necromancer subclass speak with corpse feature.

entries.title: unarmored-defense
entries.content: Unarmored Defense Requirements - Str +0 You've trained your body in such a way to allow you to effectively respond to attacks by intercepting blows and dodging projectiles. Your ac while unarmored is 14+lvl. If you have at least +1 dex, this number increases to 15+lvl.\ Gain 4 poise.

entries.title: README
entries.content: As One Requirements -  During an ally's turn, if they move, you can spend an immediate action to use your movement to move along with them. You must either end this movement within their natural reach, or threatening the same enemy as them. You subtract this movement from your movement next turn. Turn based games make movement awkward, but the idea is you are moving together, so other positional effects, such as escape route or shield actions, can treat moving allies as within reach for the duration of the movement in circumstances where allies converge on a location or start in positions that are close to each other.

entries.title: tandem-charge
entries.content: Tandem Charge Requirements - As one During an ally's turn, if they make a charge attack, you can spend an immediate action to charge along with them and make a simple attack. You must charge attack the same creature they attack Your speed is zero on your next turn. Turn based games make movement awkward, but the idea is you are moving together, so other positional effects, such as escape route or shield actions, can treat moving allies as within reach for the duration of the movement in circumstances where allies converge on a location or start in positions that are close to each other.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Bonded Mind (Su) Requirements -  You can communicate telepathically with any ally as long as you can see them.

entries.title: take-the-hit
entries.content: Take the Hit Requirements - Bonded Mind As an immediate action, when an ally within 30 ft of you takes damage, you can choose to reduce the damage by half and then take that damage as true damage.

entries.title: artillery-team
entries.content: Artillery Team Requirements -  You can use the aid action to reload an allies weapon with the reload property (like crossbow or gun). You can aid them preemptively to allow them to shoot more than once during their turn. Also siege weapons when I get to it

entries.title: cooperative-casting
entries.content: Cooperative Casting Requirements - The ability to cast spells You can use the aid action on an ally within 30 ft to increase the CL ally by 2 for 1 round. When you do this, you can also spend 1 mana to decrease the mana cost of their next spell by 1. If your level is higher than the creature you are assisting, the CL boost increases to 3.

entries.title: escape-route
entries.content: Escape Route Requirements -  Leaving threatened squares also threatened by your allies is \[elusive].

entries.title: feint-partner
entries.content: Feint Partner Requirements -  If your ally feints a creature, you can make an AoO against it if it is within reach. It is DD for this attack.

entries.title: gang-up
entries.content: Gang Up Requirements -  Gain a +4 bonus to your combat maneuver if an ally has rolled an attack against the creature you target since your last turn.

entries.title: harmonize
entries.content: Harmonize Requirements -  When you roll a group skill check with the performance skill, every ally proficient in a perform skill gives a +4 bonus.

entries.title: pack-tactics
entries.content: Pack Tactics Requirements -  As long as you are threatening the same creature as an ally, you gain flanking regardless of position.

entries.title: perfect-positioning
entries.content: Perfect Positioning Requirements -  You can move into an allies space. When you do, they can move into yours as an instant action \[elusive]. While adjacent to an ally, you cannot be flanked.

entries.content: Teamwork Feats {% hint style="danger" %} A teamwork feat requires more than one creature to possess in order to function, usually providing some kind of synergistic effect. The wording of these feats often include "all allies," but it only applies to allies with the feat. {% endhint %}

entries.title: shield-bros
entries.content: Shield Bros Requirements -  Gain +2 ac when you are within the natural reach of an ally that wields a shield. This can increase up to +4 ac if 4 shield bros are involves. Due to how spaces work on grids, having groups of 4 adjacent to each other can be difficult. So for groups, as long as each member is adjacent to another member, that should suffice for gaining this feats benefits.

entries.title: spotter
entries.content: Spotter Requirements -  When you give the aid action to grant a bonus to attack to a creature firing a ranged weapon or siege weapon, the bonus increases to +4, but you can no longer have multiple creatures to aid that creature to grant attack bonuses. You also give a +4 bonus when you aid a perception check.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Feat Functionality Feats are features in progression typically gained at every odd level. They allow your character to get bonuses to specific actions, perform entirely new actions and occasionally get general stat increases. Some feats have prerequisites, such as stat requirements or other feats. You must meet all of the requirements of a feat to take it. Feats come in a few categories. General - General feats mostly assist with some kind of out of combat task, such as things to increase the consistency of skills. Combat - A combat feat is only useful during combat, or is at least more skewed towards being useful during combat.  Multiclass - This feat allows you to borrow a feature from another class. Usually such features are secondary features of the class, or are there for flavor. Teamwork - A teamwork feat requires more than one creature to possess in order to function, usually providing some kind of synergistic effect. The wording of these feats often include "all allies," but it only applies to allies with the feat. Magic - Feats that specifically apply to spells. MM - Short for meta magic. A subsection of magic feats that allow you to apply general augments to spells by spending an additional point of mana. Most require intelligence.

entries.title: but-who-is-the-game-master
entries.content: 😱 But Who is the Game Master?! Out of everybody in the group, the game master, or GM, is the one who is undoubtedly going to be putting the most effort into the game. It can often feel like a bit of a drawing straws scenario where someone has to put up with the extra work so everybody can enjoy a game. Chances are if you are introducing a new game to your friends, you're going to be the one to run the game since you "know the rules" or whatever excuse your buddies come up with. I'm here to tell you you need not fret: Becoming a GM is easy! It's becoming a great GM that's hard. I'll give you a few hints and shortcuts that can make preparing a game from scratch, potentially even for the first time, much easier. Don't start from nothing!\ Chances are if you're playing this game, you love RPG games, anime, fantasy or all the above. You can steal all kinds of things from your previous experiences. You can steal characters, history, maybe even an entire world from your favorite media. Nintendo isn't going to sue you if you make your exploration game based off of Breath of the Wild. What they won't know won't hurt them. Start saving now.\ This is not financial advice. No but seriously. I'm still assuming a bit here, but I'm guessing you use something like twitter or YouTube for entertainment. Maybe you're even the artsy type and you browse Deviant Art or Pinterest...Though those places have become AI cesspools...Anyway, you're going to want to fill your worlds with people, places and things! Find pictures and videos that inspire you. Being inspired by something is your creative brain salivating at the idea of making it your own. Whether you find pictures of old ruins you want your players to explore, an awesome monster you want them to fight, or NPCs to fill your towns with, you need these things to make the world feel great. Maybe you can even commission someone if you're feeling generous and need something specific. I learned how to draw just to make pictures of my characters! See how others have done it.\ Just recently I decided I wanted to include a maze in my game. I have done mazes before, but they were pretty small and included a map. This made it so players could just see where they have been from me getting rid of the fog of war and made it feel like a process of elimination. But what do you do when things are more complicated? What if the maze is too big for a map? What if the maze changes? I wanted to try out something new to get a better maze feel. So I looked up how other people have done their labyrinth sessions. I decided to do something a bit more abstract where things the party found gave them clues and eventually when they gathered enough clues, they found their way through. Not exactly the true misery intended from a labyrinth, but we are trying to have fun after all. I wouldn't have had the idea if others hadn't tried it before me and posted their experience online. Maybe the weird stuff you want to do in your game you can learn from someone else's mistakes too!

entries.title: README
entries.content: Advice for Playing the Game Playing tabletop can be a daunting experience. With so many rules and mechanics that you are unfamiliar with, it may discourage you from playing. This section is to give you advice on how to make the process feel a bit less daunting. If you don't really care about what I have to say about playing the game, then skip ahead to the rules. This section is mostly intended for prospective players and game masters...Or dungeon masters, or keepers or whatever funny name you call it.

entries.title: rules-mechanics-and-expectations-oh-my
entries.content: Rules, Mechanics and Expectations, Oh My! Many people going into TTRPGs believe they are ill-prepared. I am here to tell you that even after a decade of playing, that feeling has never gone away. I'll tell you something else, my friends and I look back at the time we first started playing with nostalgia. The experience of learning a new system together with your friends can cause you to butt heads sometimes, but it reveals something incredible that is unique to tabletop: The rules are more like guidelines. Sure they structure play, and you want rules to help you decide how xyz works, but you don't need to follow every rule. I'm not going to call the Tabletop Police Force because you think how this ability works is stupid and what were the developers thinking? I do recommend writing down how you change the rules somewhere though so you can refer back to it. This is a long winded way of me saying learning rules to a complex system takes time, and fumbling through the journey is half the fun. If your worries are that you won't do a good job or you'll forget the rules then make up rules how they make sense to you, or use this incredible website to find the rule. I made this game and I forget the rules, forcing me to have to look things up. Making shit up and altering the game in ways that make it more fun is what TTRPGs are all about.

entries.title: pros-and-cons-of-ttrpgs
entries.content: Pros and Cons of TTRPGs For people unfamiliar who are considering playing Nick Nacks, here are some of the pros and cons of the hobby as a whole. Pros * Never the Same Thing Twice - If you want to talk about replayability, TTRPGs are unmatched. Every story will have moments you never forget, either because of silly moments where you roll bad, or because of epic battles where you almost died.  * The Perfect Hangout Hobby - If you are just looking for something to do with your friends and you have a lot of spare time, like if you play garbage games like League of Legends, then tabletop is a good substitute.  * Cost Effective - Going out to eat, see movies or drinking might not cost much one night, but do it every week and it adds up. If you choose TTRPGs as your hobby, you typically only need the up front cost of dice and such, and that's if you play in person. Playing on line with the right combination of programs can be completely free! * True Role-Playing - Many RPG video games will not deliver particularly well on the role-playing side of things, giving you a generic blank slate protagonist and offer little in the way of interesting or compelling choices. TTRPGs let you play whatever you want, do whatever you want and do those things however you want them. Whether you want to go full pacifist, murder hobo or a mix and match approach, you can approach problem-solving in a way no other game can really deliver on. Cons * Time Consuming - In order to get the most out of TTRPGs, you will likely need to play for several hours a sitting, with multiple sittings a month. Lots of people play weekly, around 4 hours each session for potentially dozens of sessions to finish the story. * You get what you put in - Personally, I find this as a pro, but for many it can be a con. If you aren't particularly invested in the story, if you skip many sessions, or if you aren't paying attention to when you are playing, you probably aren't going to enjoy TTRPGs much. I know especially these days it can be difficult for people to put down their phones and have a good time, and TTRPGs are one of those kinds of hobbies. * Scheduling - The sad reality of the hobby is that even if you miraculously find 4 buddies to play with, they wont always be available on Monday night. My personal recommendation is to play no matter how many players show up, even if its only 1. Solo adventures can be fun too! Gives you time to deeply explore the characters closest to the player. \ Reschedule when you can. If you don't play very often, the game loses momentum and campaigns can slowly fade out of existence.

entries.title: README
entries.content: I'm New to Tabletop Role-Playing Welcome! This section will assume you know basically nothing. What is a Tabletop Role-Playing Game (TTRPG) Anybody can play pretend (role-play), but without any structure, things tend to fall apart. TTRPGs seek to create a foundation for you to make stories with your friends (game). They are designed to be played with pen, paper and dice (hence tabletop), but such things can also be substituted for dice rolling programs and sharing your screen over discord. For a game like Nick Nacks, the idea is to let you pretend to be in a living breathing fantasy world where strange creatures like elves and goblins are the norm. It assumes you are playing a small group of people with specialized training and high ambitions. This could mean preventing world ending catastrophes from ancient powerful forces like dragons, or it could mean trying to start up a business in a cutthroat world of magic and mayhem. The moment to moment gameplay typically involves the Game Master (GM) describing environments, mannerisms of people in the world and how the world reacts to the players actions. The GM plays the role of referee and author, writing the framework for the story and arbitrating how events unfold. Players are typically presented with problems, quests and enemies to overcome with clever solutions or overwhelming force.\ A very simple interaction could involve the following sequence. Game Master - Describes details about a scenario, say an unsavory bar at a coastal town.\ Player - I want to talk to the unsavory pirates.\ Player 2 - I'll watch from the sides to make sure nobody gets up to any funny business\ Game Master - Describes how they react, what they say and how they brandish their weapons when someone unfamiliar approaches.\ Player 2 - I don't like that. I'll get ready to sneak attack them.\ Player - Hold on, maybe they're friendly.\ Game Master - They are most certainly not friendly. Player 2 roll stealth and see if you surprise...Unfortunately they see you coming, roll initiative. Combat is how you will be spending a good amount of your time. Many classes (like fighter) are designed almost exclusively to excel in combat. More details on that below. What is combat? In fantasy, you will encounter a wide variety of problems: Magical rituals that need to be stopped, infestations of giant rats and shapeshifters weaved amongst political allies. Combat is not always necessary, as some players may enjoy trying to solve problems with their wits over their weapons. But combat is inevitable in some situations, where ideals clash and lives are on the line. Some players only really care about the combat. It takes a bit of playing the game yourself to figure out where you fall on the spectrum. Nick Nacks, and games like it, are turn based. The way initiative works guarantees a back and forth battle between the party of players and their foes. One player decides what they want to do, then an enemy, then an ally and so on. You fill your turns with spells and attacks until you complete your goal, none of your enemies remain, they surrender, or you need to make a hasty retreat. Do I have to do a funny voice? The role-playing aspect of Nick Nacks is what sets it apart from many other games like World of Warcraft or Skyrim. These games might advertise themselves as role-playing, but the choices you get to make are usually pretty slim. In skyrim when you approach a locked door, you can either pick it or use a key. Some doors don't even let you pick them for story reasons. Nice thief character! In tabletop when you approach a locked door, you can pick it, you can break it down with raw strength, explosives. You can use magical abilities to circumvent it by shrinking to fit into the key hole. You can dig under or over it. Your ability to solve problems has limitations, but your options are typically only limited to your ability to imagine a solution. Not to mention, this is just a simple problem. Imagine the kinds of creative solutions you'll need to employ during a prison break or finding who is spying on the king! The funny voice is short hand for speaking in character with an accent, and you do it as much as you want. Once upon a time, GMs may have not even allowed people to speak in character. You can use your voice, some other voice, or you can choose to only describe what your character wants to say. You could also just decide to be mute! I'm no voice actor, and I focus more on trying to stay in character more than trying to get any voice right.  You are playing a game after all, your main priority should be to have fun!

entries.title: pros-and-cons-of-nick-nacks
entries.content: Pros and Cons of Nick Nacks For more experienced TTRPG players, you might already have a good idea of what you like in a system, so this section will (hopefully) be an easy way to figure out if you will like Nick Nacks.  Pros * Customization - A robust system designed to be played over and over again with characters that feel different every time. Customization with creative character ideas is the number one thing I set out to accomplish in Nick Nacks.  * Balance - The second highest priority I have, that is absolutely necessary in order to make customization possible, is balance. Games that I have played struggle to maintain balance, particularly in the early/later levels and with their magic systems. I pay very close attention to features when they seem particularly powerful and particularly weak, and make adjustments as needed. * Adaptive - I don't have plans to print anything for this game, and regularly update this website. If a feature ends up a power outlier, or doesn't feel how it should, I will go back and change it to make it better. No longer will you need to wait decades for a new book to come out, contact the developers on twitter or pray your GM rules in your favor. * Free! - This website doesn't have a subscription and is more of a "pay want you want" via patreon. If you do what I did when I started playing, you can use dice rolling programs like rolz for your dice needs, discord for voice chat and screen sharing and your art program of choice for battlemaps. Personally I make mine in pain tool sai, then share them in gimp because its easier to move layers around. Sai isn't free, but gimp is a nice alternative for making battle maps. Cons * Incomplete - As a solo developer who cannot dedicate 100% of my time to this project, you will inevitably find certain classes and spell lists with not as much content as you were hoping. You will also find artifacts of me copy and pasting things, or me making large scale rules changes and not catching every single feature it effects. Everything I start, I intend to finish, but starting things is a lot easier than finishing them. * Complex - When I make content, I always make considerations to speed up play, but inevitably if you want a robust system of customization, you increase the complexity of the game. This means that you will likely not be able to remember all the fine details of the hundreds of spells, class features and feats the game has to offer. I tried my best to organize this website as well as I could to make the process of looking things up fast, and because you're playing tabletop, you can adjust things to be more convenient on the fly and look things up later if you don't want to slow things down. * No Game World - One area in particular that will take a very long time to finish that is lower on the priority list is fleshing out a game world. I have introduced several mechanics that have world-building elements built into them such as mana, races and gods. Luckily, most of you probably already have high-fantasy game worlds you like. * D20 System - For the math nerds out there, this can be a problem. The d20 is exceptionally good a delivering highlights and is quite simple. It is probably the most familiar type of action resolution dice, but as a tradeoff it is not the most mathematically sound. With a soft bounded accuracy system like Nick Nacks, its less of an issue, but there will be times where you reach the extremes of the dice and foil the balance I worked so hard to achieve.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Alternate Win Conditions For when killing everything that moves isn't what you want. Alternate win conditions seek to answer the question of "how do I end combat without reducing the enemy hp to 0."

entries.title: restraint
entries.content: Restraint When creatures surrender but you don’t want to risk killing them. Some situations can naturally be neutralized by dropping a cage in the right place, but such conveniences are rare. More often restraining your foe is going to involves rope and cuffs. {% tabs %} {% tab title="Cuffs" %} Poise breaking an already grappled creature allows you to put cuffs on them. This completely prevents the use of their arms outside of simple item interactions. Cuffs can also be placed on the legs to reduce a creatures speed to 15. Combat maneuvers made against a cuffed creature have advantage.\ Cuffs are difficult to escape, and even harder to break. They typically require outside assistance in order to be removed. Because cuffs are typically made from iron and steel, they can take a significant beating. {% endtab %} {% tab title="Rope" %} Poise breaking a grappled creature allows you tie them up, having the same effect as applying cuffs. The main difference is that rope is easier to destroy, but it is also easier to make the restraint more intense. By successfully poise breaking a creature a 3rd time, you can prevent the creature from acting completely. Rope tends to be a good way to bind singular creatures without allies, since anybody with a sharp implement can handily free a bound creature. {% endtab %} {% tab title="Dog Pile" %} By having 3 different creatures simultaneously grappling another creature, you can prevent that creature from acting completely as long as all 3 maintain their grapple. By spending all of your turns, you can move the creature 15 ft a turn.\ Dogpiles are broken the instant one creatures stops grappling, making them unreliable. {% endtab %} {% tab title="Contained" %} By succeeding at breaking an already grappled creature's poise, you can forcefully shove them into an object within reach such as a bag, barrel or box, so long as they can handily fit in the object. Whether or not they can escape generally depends on the object and the tools the captured creature has on hand. Wooden crates don’t do to well when trying to hold barbarians or crafty characters with crowbars. {% endtab %} {% endtabs %} Below are more precise details on the DCs to break, unlock and escape if you find yourself in a bind. {% tabs %} {% tab title="Cuffs" %} DC to break (athletics) or lockpick (SoH) is dependent on the type of material. Athletics tends to be less subtle. Solid toughness is DC 25.\ Adamantine toughness is 35.\ Transmundane is 40. Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty. {% endtab %} {% tab title="Rope" %} Rope can be destroyed with an attack from any slashing weapon.\ Using athletics you can tear the ropes apart, but the DC is determined by the athletics bonus of the creature who bound you (20+their athletics bonus).\ Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty. This penalty can be ignored with a sharp natural attack or concealed weapon. {% endtab %} {% tab title="Contained" %} DC to break (athletics) is dependent on the type of material. Some objects can be handily dealt with, not requiring a skill check. A knife makes quick work of a bag, and given enough space, hammers break boxes. Fragile toughness is DC 15\ Average toughness is DC 20.\ Solid toughness is DC 25.\ Adamantine toughness is DC 35.\ Transmundane toughness is DC 40 Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty. {% endtab %} {% endtabs %}

entries.title: surrender-morale
entries.content: 🏳️ Surrender/Morale During combat there come times when you do not wish to fight, usually when one side is close to victory, but can also happen when creatures are clearly outnumbered or outmatched. How well a surrender feels in a situation usually comes down to a gut feeling, affected by a lot of variables. In order to even consider a surrender to be viable, one or more of the following (or other applicable) conditions should be met… \>Numbers advantage\ \>Some other clear advantage, such as terrain, positioning, equipment or a powerful noteworthy ally\ \>Heavily damaged or unconscious allies\ \>Consequences for not surrendering (often death or further prosecution)\ \>Hostages\ \>Whether or not creatures are minions or named characters A surrender requires clear communication, which may not always be possible given the hectic and spread out nature of battle. Some creatures, particularly mindless ones, will not surrender unless specific circumstances are met. Creatures of animal intelligence can be convinced to surrender if you can speak to animals or have wild empathy etc.   Surrender can mean forfeiting weapons, fleeing in fear, begging for mercy or something similar.

entries.title: truce
entries.content: Truce In situations where there are two opposing sides that are generally neutral towards each other or even allies with each other, you can call for a truce. This generally requires important information (we were sent by the merchants guild), certification from an important or recognizable organization (legal documentation) or a special item (an artifact or flag). It could also be appropriate to call for a truce if you are delving into a dungeon and encounter another party, so long as you aren't after the same thing. You might not cooperate, but at least you won't be killing each other. If more information is revealed by talking throughout a battle (wait you're also hunting for the garbooni?), you can also reasonably call for a truce.

entries.title: ashen-one
entries.content: Ashen One In dark souls, certain types of creatures, namely the player character, hold a special place in the world's lore. When you die you don't reload the game, you canonically respawn at the location you last rested, leaving behind all your money where you died. You could choose to adopt a similar system where certain types of conditions need to be met for these unique creatures to die for real. Having the characters lose all their money might not be the best approach for a TTRPG: players like their money. But in souls games you can go back to the place you died and collect the money again so maybe. This kind of natural respawn mechanic is a good fit for campaigns where you expect your players to encounter dangerous creatures on the regular and your players don't get too discouraged from losing. Meat grinder without the consequences of losing your character for good.

entries.title: cloning-devices
entries.content: Cloning Devices You start off your adventures waking up in some alchemist's lab, surrounded in copies of yourself. Whenever you die, there is a fresh body waiting for you back at the lab that your soul gets sucked into. This plays more into having a secret base type thing, and it feels a little less metagame-y than "chosen by god." it also has an interesting mystery component to it. Why were you guys chosen as clones? Whose lab is this? How's that for storytelling with resurrection?

entries.title: gods-good-graces
entries.content: God's Good Graces In the event of your characters untimely demise, worry not, for the gods smile upon you. When killed, your body becomes a tombstone with your name and face on it. It weighs as much as you did, including all of your equipment. This tombstone can be carried back somewhere to perform a ritual and bring the character back to life, or destroyed to end them permanently and get their loot. This can be a place of significance to this god, something generic like a church or something with more story relevance. It can be wherever home base is, or you can require the players to reach certain points in the campaign in order to get their characters resurrected (your friend died by the lich's hand, now to get them back you have to destroy his phylactery, make a temp character >:).  The basic idea is there: satisfy this entity's conditions and life will be restored.

entries.title: limited-resurrection
entries.content: Limited Resurrection Pose a caveat to resurrection magic that imposes a severely limiting factor, such as only being able to revive a creature shortly after it died with some kind of resource attached to it. Maybe even make it a limited resource by tying it to physical items, like scrolls with this effect attached to it.  EFFECT RangeReachTargetOne dead creatureDurationinstantaneous DESCRIPTION\ You breathe new life into a recently deceased creature. If the creature has died within the last minute, they are brought back to life at 1 hp and drained 1.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Plot Armor? The basic premise of this system of resurrection is that you want player death to have immediate consequences: Not being able to complete a mission or delaying the players long enough so that way the villain can complete the ritual. But you don't want them to have long-term consequences: Not being able to play your character. Having to go on lengthy multi-session quests to find someone willing and able to cast the correct spell to bring you back can be fun, but after a few times, it can get old. So in order to achieve the former and avoid the latter, it's recommended that you bake the reason for the players coming back from the dead into the story. Death still matters or course, after all the players will have allies (:< If your players aren't too attached to their characters, then who needs plot armor? Let 'em die. If they are, consider some of the options below.

entries.title: withers
entries.content: Withers In Baldur's Gate 3, there is an npc that shows up in your camp that has a vested interest in your success. He has powers that aren't like normal characters, chief among them the ability to resurrect fallen allies. You could easily introduce a similar character into your campaign, maybe even the introduction to the campaign is this npc resurrecting the players. This particular method has the benefit of being less nebulous than divine forces. It gives someone the players can interact with and someone that can give them direction. Whatever the reason they have for resurrecting your players, it's because they need their help.

entries.title: README
entries.content: Death and Resurrection Let's be honest, the purpose of resurrection in TTRPGs is primarily for the benefit of the players. If a DM makes frequent use of the resurrection spells for entities that the players went to great lengths to kill, it heavily undermines their effort and feels terrible, even if plausible. If all it takes is a bunch of money and a cleric then rich high level players live in a world without death as a consequence for anybody. Now that we all agree about that, why does resurrection have an expensive material component cost? To punish the players for being unlucky? Why is it locked behind high-level magic? To make playing cleric mandatory? If we only consider the players, then these things become very obvious problems. Players shouldn't be shoehorned into playing specific classes, nor should the money that they worked hard to obtain be required to continue playing the game. The powers that be should instead be very particular about the who gets a second chance. If the players are the main character of the story, then the game's resurrection mechanics should treat them as such. As a replacement for most resurrection effects, use these rules instead. Or don't use resurrection at all. It's your game. Whatever. {% hint style="warning" %} Please make sure your players are on board with whatever you decide. Nobody likes surprise mechanics. {% endhint %}

entries.title: charisma
entries.content: 💞 Charisma Charisma Basics The ability to lead others and personal magnetism are what characterize charisma. * Positive charisma enhances your companion creatures (see below). Any creature that takes a companion slot gains attack equal to your charisma * Gain a contact per point of charisma (see below) * With positive charisma, you gain a teamwork feat. You can share this teamwork feat. See more details below.\ - You lose a companion slot with negative charisma - A negative charisma score makes it difficult to coordinate/train your companion. They lose attack equal to your negative charisma. - You cannot benefit from teamwork feats Companions In media it's very common for creatures to have minions, squires and sidekicks. This is what the companion system is for. Like most other content, the companion system is ill-suited for large quantities of creatures, like armies. Its meant to be more compact. Something to take with you on the go for your adventure. This could also reasonably extend to temporary lesser allies that join your party. Companions are generally tied to your class, abilities and items. Any such ability is marked with the \[companion] tag. * You are limited to 2 companion slots * Companions always act on your turn if you are present. There is no separation between your turns, you all act in the same initiative. * Companions gain a bonus or penalty to attack based off of your charisma Contacts A contact is a friend from the past. A creature (so not necessarily humanoid) that can either be relied on to come to you when needed, or to always stay in one place. Contacts are always specialized in one particular task, such as tracking, making weapons, or running an inn. A contact doesn't always offer you free services, but they are typically willing to give you better services, drop other clients to assist you and in general try their best to keep you "in the loop."  Depending on the nature of your game, all contacts might be wanderers, or they might all reside in a handful of settlements you frequent. Teamwork With positive charisma, you gain a teamwork feat. You can share a single teamwork feat you possess with a number of creatures equal to your charisma bonus. In order to share a teamwork feat, you need to perform training exercises for 1 hour with the creatures you intend to team up with.  Bestiary Examples * Visualizing charisma | negative | | | -------- | ---------------- | | moderate | Gnome, horse | | high | Succ, ligma male |

entries.title: dexterity
entries.content: Dexterity Dexterity Basics Agility, sneakiness and how good you are with your hands are what characterize dexterity * Depending on your choice in armor, you can add your dexterity to your AC, but you always add it to poise * You add dexterity to attack/dmg with ranged weapons and light weapons (but not at the same time as strength) - You add dexterity to your reflex save\ * Negative dexterity (usually) subtracts from these values Bestiary Examples * Visualizing Dexterity | negative | Giants, oozes | | -------- | ---------------------- | | moderate | Cats, small creatures | | high | Elementals, quicklings |

entries.title: intelligence
entries.content: 🧠 Intelligence Intelligence Basics The quantity of things you know and your proficiency in the mechanics of magic characterize intelligence. * You gain an additional skill proficiency per point of intelligence * You gain two additional languages per point of intelligence * Gain a point in your mana reserves per each point of intelligence * Get an additional point of memory per point of intelligence\ - You lose a skill proficiency per negative point of intelligence - Lose a memory slot per point of negative intelligence Sentience A creature is considered sentient if it has at least -2 intelligence. These creatures typically do not speak, but can understand at least 1 language. Most magical beasts fall in this category. Animal intelligence is -3 intelligence. Creatures with animal intelligence only understand simple commands (if anything). They are usually limited to their instinctual urges. Mindless creatures possess no will of their own. They act completely on instinct. Bestiary Examples * Visualizing intelligence | mindless | Undead minions, many oozes | | -------- | ------------------------------------------------ | | animal | Most beasts | | negative | Nyagas, trolls, anybody that isn't you | | moderate | Wise mystical tree, great mighty poo | | high | The time lord, mind flayers, nalfeshne, beholder |

entries.title: luck
entries.content: 🎲 Luck Luck Basics The ability to turn the tides in a negative situation and getting more favorable outcomes when things are uncertain are what characterizes luck. * As an immediate action, you can add your luck to any D20 roll. Luck cannot be added to a roll twice. Luck cannot be added when you take 10, 20 etc. * Added to luck/serendipity checks * Get a boon at character creation for each point of luck\   - Negative luck imposes a penalty to all DCs equal to the negative value. - Subtracted from luck checks - Get a bane on character creation for each point of negative luck Serendipity When playing table top, a lot of things aren't well defined until they get into render distance, which basically means when players ask about it. When a situation pops up where your player asks for a specific circumstance like "Is the door to the armory locked?" "is there a hat store in town?" or "are there any footholds on the side of this cliff?" and you don't immediately have a response, the character in question rolls a luck check. If it's a general party question, or if you bring your lucky friend with you during your shopping trip, they could reasonably roll it instead. * Examples | Likelihood (of being favorable) | DC | Description | | ------------------------------- | -- | ----------------------------------------------- | | Likely | 5 | "Are there footholds on the side of this cliff" | | Plausible | 10 | "Is there a hat store in town?" | | Unlikely | 15 | "Is the door to this person's house locked?" | | Very Unlikely | 20 | "Any human meat for sale?" | | Usually Impossible | 25 | "There any lava pools in this forest?" | Again, if you already had an answer in mind, don't roll this.\ This is something that you should use in moderation. The moment you let your players start rolling this again and again is when all cohesion in your world evaporates Bestiary Examples * Visualizing Luck | negative | Me and you, Harambe | | -------- | --------------------------------------- | | moderate | Succ, Bane, Mimic | | high | Fey creatures, followers of Frogg Saran |

entries.title: README
entries.content: Ability Scores There are 6 in total: \ Strength (Str)\ Dexterity (Dex)\ Luck (Lucc)\ Intelligence (Int) \ Wisdom (Wis)\ Charisma (Cha)

entries.title: strength
entries.content: 💪 Strength Strength Basics Lifting capacity, the ability to swing heavy weapons and wear heavy armors, fortitude and athletics are what characterize strength. * You add your strength to fortitude saves * You add your strength to poise * Every point of strength increases your carry weight by 100 (see below for more details) * Every point of strength increases your jump distance by 5 ft with the jump action\ - Negative strength subtracts from your fortitude saves - Every negative point of strength halves your carry weight Carry Weight A creatures carry rate represents what is capable of lifting and moving around with without much effort.\ The default value is 100lbs.\ A creature can lift and drag twice as much as their carry weight, but is staggered while doing so. Bestiary Examples * Visualizing Strength negativeYummi, clovermoderateBull, gym broshighBalor, NJU, Trex

entries.title: wisdom
entries.content: 🙏 Wisdom Wisdom Basics Your faith, ability to resist mental influence and notice things in the world are what characterizes wisdom. * You add your wisdom to will save * You add your wisdom to perception, the skill all creatures get for free * You can pray to your god for guidance (see below for details). You can use prayer a number of times per day equal to your wisdom bonus * Positive wisdom automatically puts you into T1 favor in one god. 1k GBP per point * Characters with positive wisdom multiply GBP gains by (1+wis)\ - Negative wisdom instead subtracts will saves and perception - Negative wisdom represents a complete lack of faith in most gods, you cannot gain GBP (unless in service of Frogg Saran) Prayer Prayer requires 1 minute of uninterrupted concentration. You get a number of uses of prayer equal to (wisdom+tier of favor). Because positive wisdom grants T1 favor in a god, you usually start with wis+1 uses of prayer. You gain impressions from the future about something in specific. When you initially start praying, you must mention a specific action (attack the bandits, pet the dog etc.). When the prayer is complete, gain a nugget information about whether this action will bring favorable or unfavorable results to within the next half hour. The answer does not take into account consequences into the future past 30 minutes. * Results | Weal | The action will give mostly good results | | ------------ | ------------------------------------------------------ | | Woe | The action will give mostly bad results | | Weal and Woe | The action will give good and bad results | | Nothing | The action won't have particularly good or bad results | Bestiary Examples * Visualizing Wisdom | negative | Beholders | | -------- | ---------------------------------------------- | | moderate | Owls, treants | | high | Wise mystical tree, The inevitable, Banageddon |

entries.title: defeat
entries.content: ⚰️ Defeat When you take damage that reduces you to zero or lower, you are defeated, and must be healed to regain consciousness in a timely manner. You can choose to non-lethally defeat someone provided you are using a manufactured weapon, unarmed strike or natural attack. If this is not the case, they must make a DC 8 luck check or die. Creatures that manage to survive being defeated have to keep making this luck check every time they take damage while defeated. When a main character (ie usually the players) falls to zero HP, they can take no actions on their turn and can only crawl at 15 speed (they have the defeated condition). When a character recovers from the defeated condition, their next turn they are dazed. When you are defeated or when you take damage while defeated, you receive 1 stack of drain. When recovering from the defeated condition, you also gain an affliction. More rules on those in the afflictions section. Main characters also don't run the risk of dying when defeated. Instead of rolling luck checks, a main character gets a stack of doom when they take damage while defeated. Upon acquiring the 5th stack, they die. Doom stacks are lost on rest.

entries.title: README
entries.content: ❤️ Hitpoints (HP) How much hp a player has is largely determined by their class. Creatures have a base hp value of 20, and then a value that they add each level, including level one. Classes and creatures all fall under one of the following categories based on their play style. See chart below for more details. Class TypeHP/lvl DescriptionSpecialist6Specialist creatures rely almost solely on spellcasting and supernatural abilities. They have a great many skills in their repertoire. They tend to have unusual defensive qualities, but a few solid hits are usually enough to take them down.Mixed8Mixed creatures tend to be somewhere in between martials and specialists. They usually combine supernatural abilities and spells with weapon strikes or are capable of doing either, but not quite as well as a martial or specialist.Martial10Martials creatures have limited supernatural abilities that aren't directly tied to weapon attacks, however they tend to have a bit more nuance to their strategy than brutes. They usually have high attack and AC.Brute12Brute creatures rely almost solely on hitting things very hard to solve all their problems. On top of high hp, they usually have other extraordinary defensive qualities like damage reduction, resistance and healing. They usually require heavy focus to take down.

entries.title: temp-hp-healing
entries.content: Temp HP/Healing In general healing is accessible, with the jizzle physick being a primary component to the game. Allowing you to theoretically fight on forever. Effects with the \[overheal] tag grant temp hp equal to excess healing past your maximum. Temp HP There are also many sources of temporary hitpoints, shorthand temp hp. All sources of temp hp do not stack, and you only take the highest value of what you have. Unless otherwise stated, temp hp only lasts 1 minute. Natural Healing In the absence of danger, a defeated creature will regain 1 hp after 1 hour. They are staggered until they are healed or they rest. With a proper 8 hours rest, a character restores all their HP, all of their daily use abilities and recover mana burn. You can only rest once each day.

entries.title: publish-your-docs
entries.content: ‼️ Common Combat Actions {% tabs %} {% tab title="Dash" %} Action Type: Standard\ Double your speed this round. Has no effect if your speed is zero. {% endtab %} {% tab title="Charge" %} Action Type: FRA\ Move at twice your speed in a straight line, halting when your foe is adjacent, or at least within reach. Make your attack(s) against a creature. Creatures get a +2 bonus to attack against you until the start of your next turn. If your charge gets interrupted for whatever reason, you must make your attack(s) from your halted position. You cannot charge a creature that is adjacent to you. {% endtab %} {% tab title="Disengage" %} Action Type: Standard\ Completely focus on finding openings in the battlefield. Your movement is \[elusive] this turn, making it not provoke attacks of opportunity (AoO). {% endtab %} {% tab title="Jump" %} Action Type: Swift\ Can only be used in combination with other forms of movement such as walking or charging. Jump once 5 feet long or half that in height. This does not give you additional movement, and the thus it is limited by your speed. Can be used to avoid difficult terrain or hazards. Jump action can only be made 1/turn. If you dash and take the jump action, you can jump twice with the same swift action. Jump distance increases by 5 ft per point of strength (or dexterity if trained in acrobatics). You cannot jump while standing in a hazardous surface that would normally have some kind of negative effect while moving through it, such as difficult terrain or tripping and falling in an oil spill. You can jump over them just fine, just not if you're already stuck in them. {% endtab %} {% tab title="Potion" %} Action Type: Swift\ Retrieve and drink a potion, or similar type of consumable. Provokes AoOs. {% endtab %} {% tab title="Aid" %} Action Type: Standard\ Give an ally within your natural reach one of the following bonuses for 1 round: +2 attack, +2 saves, +2 AC. Or get rid of 1 stack of clumsy, shaken, sickened, knockdown. Many effects that entangle and snare can be removed with athletics. You can use the aid action to help an ally escape. You can aid a defeated creature bringing them to 1 hp when not in combat.
